case_name: Continental Export and Import Company v. Income-tax authorities

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 325 and 326 of 1960 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 325 and 326 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated February 21, 1956, of the former Andhra High Court in case Referred No. 50 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated February 21, 1956, of the former Andhra High Court in case Referred No. 50 of 1954.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on January 16, 1962 by HIDAYATULLAH J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. January 16.-The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH J.-The appellant is a firm at Gudur  Andhra Pradesh

facts.text: Appellant is a firm at Gudur, Andhra Pradesh, doing business in Mica under the name Continental Export and Import Company.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a firm at Gudur  Andhra Pradesh , which was doing busines Mica under the name and style of the Continental Export and Import Company.

facts.text: During years of account 1948-49 and 1949-50 corresponding to assessment years 1949-50 and 1950-51, assessee firm exported Mica to Japan.

anchor.surface_text: During the years of account, 1948-49 and 1949-50  companyresponding to the assessment years, 1949-50 and 1950-51 , the assessee firm exported Mica to Japan.

facts.text: Mica was not directly exportable to Japanese buyers as Japan was under military occupation, but to Boeki-Cho Board of Trade.

anchor.surface_text: Mica was number directly exportable to Japanese buyers during these years, as Japan was under military occupation, but to a State Organisation called Boeki-Cho  Board of Trade .

facts.text: Assessee firm engaged San-Ei Trading Co. Ltd., Tokyo, as its agents in Japan.

anchor.surface_text: To negotiate for order and to handle its other affairs in Japan in companynection therewith, the assessee firm engaged San-Ei Trading Co. Ltd., Tokyo, as its agents.

facts.text: Japanese Company was a non-resident company.

anchor.surface_text: The Japanese Company was admittedly a number-resident Company.

facts.text: Two agreements entered: first for quarter July to September 1948 with 4% commission on gross sale proceeds.

anchor.surface_text: Two agreements were entered into by the assessee firm and the Japanese Company, the first for the quarter, July to September 1948, during which period a companymission of 4 per cent on the gross sale proceeds was payable

facts.text: Second agreement for indefinite period with commission reduced to 2%.

anchor.surface_text: and the second, for an indefinite period, with the companymission reduced to 2 per cent.

facts.text: Commission due: Rs. 26,254-9-1 for 1948-49 and Rs. 11,272-8-8 for 1949-50.

anchor.surface_text: During the years of account the amount companymission due to the Japanese Company was respectively Rs. 26,254-9-1 and Rs. 11,272-8-8.

facts.text: Amounts included in price of Mica exported and received by assessee firm in India.

anchor.surface_text: These amounts  included in the price of Mica exported  were received by the assessee firm in India,

facts.text: Amounts could not be sent to Japanese Company due to Exchange Control laws restrictions.

anchor.surface_text: but due to the restrictions imposed by the Exchange Control laws, they companyld number be sent to the Japanese Company

facts.text: Agreements provided for crediting amounts to Japanese Company's account without remitting until instructions.

anchor.surface_text: The agreements between the assessee firm and the Japanese Company, therefore, provided for this companytingency by the inclusion of the following term In view of the difficulties in this companyntry it is requested that the first party credits all these amounts to the account of the second party with them without remitting the same until definite instructions are received by the first party.

facts.text: Total Rs. 13,319-12-4 paid to Japanese Company directly or through others as instructed during two account years.

anchor.surface_text: During the two account years, a total amount of Rs. 13, 319-12-4 was paid to the Japanese Company either directly or through others, to whom the assessee firm was instructed by the Japanese Company to pay the amount.

facts.text: Income-tax authorities treated assessee firm as statutory agent of Japanese Company and assessed tax on the two amounts.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax authorities treated the assessee firm as the statutory agent of the Japanese Company, and assessed tax on the two amounts in the respective years of assessment.

facts.text: Order of Income-tax Officer confirmed on appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Income-tax officer was companyfirmed on appeal

facts.text: Tribunal set aside the order holding income accrued or arisen in Japan and not received in taxable territories.

anchor.surface_text: but the Tribunal set aside the order on the ground that the income to the Japanese Company had accrued or arisen in Japan and companyld number be said to have been received by the Japanese Company in the taxable territories, since s. 4 1  a  was subordinate to s. 4 1  c .

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax obtained reference to High Court of Madras on specific question.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax, however, obtained a reference to the High Court of Madras on the question Whether the aforesaid sum of Rs. 26,255-0-0 and Rs. 11,272-0-0 being selling companymission credited to the aforesaid number- resident companypanys account

facts.text: High Court answered the question against the assessee firm.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question against the assessee firm.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate for appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, granted a certificate, and these appeals have been filed.

facts.text: Supreme Court held assessee firm as statutory agent under s.42.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, there is numberdoubt that the assessee firm must be treated as a statutory agent.

facts.text: Business connection subsisted between assessee and Japanese company.

anchor.surface_text: There can be numberquestion in this case that a business companynection subsisted during the years in question,

facts.text: Amounts credited to Japanese Company's account in assessee's books constituted receipt by Japanese Company in taxable territories.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the amount must be held, on the terms of the agreement, to have been received by the Japanese Company, and this attracts the application of s. 4  1  a .

facts.text: Japanese Company disposed of part of amounts by instructions to assessee.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, the Japanese Company did disposes of a part of those amounts by instructing the assessee firm that they be applied in a particular way.

facts.text: High Court right in answering question against assessee.

concepts.unlisted_description: Income received or deemed to be received in taxable territories

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 42, all income, profits or gains accruing or arising, whether directly, or indirectly through or from any business companynection in the taxable territories are deemed to be income accruing or arising within the taxable territories, and if the person entitled to the income, profits or gains is number resident in the taxable territories, it is chargeable to income- tax either in his name or in the name of his agent,

concepts.interpretation: Creates vicarious liability on agent for non-resident's tax, with safeguard to retain estimated liability

concepts.unlisted_description: Deems income from business connection in taxable territories; statutory agent liability

anchor.surface_text: Section 43 lays down who can be deemed to be an agent, and it is provided that any person having any business companynection with a numberresident person or through whom the number-resident is in receipt of any income, profits or gains is to be deemed to be such an agent, if the Income-tax Officer has caused a numberice to be served of his intention of treating him as the agent of the numberresident person. Such persons are companyveniently described as statutory agents.

issues.text: Whether the aforesaid sum of Rs. 26,255-0-0 and Rs. 11,272-0-0 being selling commission credited to the aforesaid non-resident company's account in the Books of the assessee are chargeable in the hands of the assessee under s. 4(1)(a) for the assessment years 1949-50 and 1950-51?

arguments.claim: Income to the Japanese Company had accrued or arisen in Japan and could not be said to have been received in taxable territories since s.4(1)(a) subordinate to s.4(1)(c); s.4(1)(a) provides general cover for (b) and (c), cannot add new liability for non-residents beyond accrual in taxable territories

anchor.surface_text: but the Tribunal set aside the order on the ground that the income to the Japanese Company had accrued or arisen in Japan and could not be said to have been received by the Japanese Company in the taxable territories, since s. 4 1  a  was subordinate to s. 4 1  c . The Tribunal thus concluded The reference in section 4 1  a  to income received in India can, in our opinion, refer only to the situation more specifically provided for in section 4 1  b  as sub-section a  provides a general cover for both the immediately following sub- sections  b  and  c .

arguments.claim: Japanese Company did not actually receive the money in taxable territories; only debtor-creditor relation until actual payment

anchor.surface_text: The contention is that this clause cannot be deemed to be received in the taxable territories then British India in the years of account. It is urged that the Japanese Company did not actually receive it in British India, and that there was only a relation of debtor and creditor between the assessee firm and the Japanese Company.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: f s.4 1  can be read disjunctively, and cl.  a , which provides for receipt of income, profits and gains in the taxable territories cannot be subjecte

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreement terms provided for crediting as deposit at disposal of Japanese Company, changing character from debt

arguments.claim: Mere entry in account books not a receipt by Japanese Company; Act always states clearly when fiction deems entry as receipt

anchor.surface_text: Till the money was actually paid over to the Japanese Company, a mere entry in the account books of the firm was not a receipt by the Japanese Company, and a mere entry of an item in the account books has not been deemed to be a receipt by any provision of the Act, which, it is said, always states clearly when a fiction is to be applied.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: f s.4 1  can be read disjunctively, and cl.  a , which provides for receipt of income, profits and gains in the taxable territories cannot be subjecte

arguments.court_reasoning: No need for fiction; agreement itself makes crediting a receipt as money held on behalf of Company

arguments.claim: Clause (a) of s.4(1) delimited by clause (c); clauses interdependent

anchor.surface_text: It is also argued that cl. a of s. 4 1 is delimited by cl. c . Clauses a and c of s.4 1 are not interdependent.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: uthorities to have recourse to the fiction. After referring to certain authorities in which this was so held, this Court pointed out Section 4 1  a  i

arguments.court_reasoning: Clauses (a) and (c) read disjunctively; (a) general and applies independently to receipt regardless of accrual

arguments.claim: Actual or deemed receipt of income in taxable territories by or on behalf of non-residents attracts tax under s.4(1)(a) even if not chargeable under s.4(1)(c); receipt alone sufficient

anchor.surface_text: Actual or deemed receipt, of income in the taxable territories by or on behalf of nonresidents attracts tax under section 4 1 a even though the income may not be chargeable under section 4 1 c by reason of its having accrued or arisen outside. Receipt of income within the taxable territories by itself attracts tax

court_response_anchor.surface_text: person a sum equal to his estimated liability. The section thus creates a vicarious liability, in so far as the agent is companycerned, for the tax w

arguments.court_reasoning: Endorsed as plain language; clauses disjunctive

arguments.claim: Assessee firm is statutory agent under ss.42 and 43 due to business connection with non-resident

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, there is no doubt that the assessee firm must be treated as a statutory agent. In Turner Morrison Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax 1 , this Court held that a person who is not an agent of the non- resident person can be appointed an agent for the purposes of s. 43, provided there subsists a business connection

arguments.claim: Business connection subsisted between assessee firm and Japanese company during relevant years

anchor.surface_text: There can be no question in this case that a business connection subsisted during the years in question,

arguments.claim: Clauses (a) and (c) of s.4(1) read disjunctively; cl.(a) not confined or dependent on accrual/arising in taxable territories; receipt sufficient

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, clauses a and c of s.4 1 can be read disjunctively, and cl. a , which provides for receipt of income, profits and gains in the taxable territories cannot be subjected to the limitation that the income must also accrue or arise in the taxable territories. To make cl. a depend on cl. c is to make the accrual the test, while cl. a only considers receipt in the taxable territories sufficient.

arguments.claim: Amounts credited to Japanese Company's account per agreement constitute receipt in taxable territories under s.4(1)(a); changed from debt to deposit at disposal

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the amount must be held, on the terms of the agreement, to have been received by the Japanese Company, and this attracts the application of s. 4 1 a . Indeed, the Japanese Company did dispose of a part of those amounts by instructing the assessee firm that they be applied in a particular way.

arguments.claim: High Court right in answering question against assessee

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court was right in the answer it gave to the question,

holdings.text: The assessee firm must be treated as a statutory agent of the Japanese Company under sections 42 and 43 of the Income Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, there is no doubt that the assessee firm must be treated as a statutory agent. In Turner Morrison Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax  1 , this Court held that a person who is not an agent of the non- resident person can be appointed an agent for the purposes of s. 43, provided there subsists a business connection

holdings.reasoning_summary: Business connection exists; cites Turner Morrison precedent applying ss.42-43 to appoint agent for non-resident's tax liability.

holdings.text: A business connection subsisted between the assessee firm and the non-resident Japanese Company during the years in question.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no question in this case that a business connection subsisted during the years in question, and the appellant firm could be treated as an assessee for purposes of s. 42.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed from facts of agency agreement for handling affairs in Japan.

holdings.text: Clauses (a) and (c) of section 4(1) are to be read disjunctively; clause (a) providing for receipt of income in taxable territories is independent and not delimited by accrual or arising under clause (c).

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, clauses a and c of s.4 1 can be read disjunctively, and cl. a , which provides for receipt of income, profits and gains in the taxable territories cannot be subjected to the limitation that the income must also accrue or arise in the taxable territories.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation; clauses capable of independent operation; receipt alone sufficient for taxability; rejects subordination argument.

holdings.text: The amounts credited to the Japanese Company's account in the assessee's books, per the terms of the agreement, constitute receipt by the Japanese Company in the taxable territories under section 4(1)(a).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement terms treat crediting as deposit at disposal of Company, changing from debt to receipt; no fiction needed; partial disposal confirms control.

holdings.text: The sums of Rs. 26,255-0-0 and Rs. 11,272-0-0 being selling commission credited to the non-resident company's account are chargeable in the hands of the assessee under s. 4(1)(a) for assessment years 1949-50 and 1950-51; High Court was right.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court was right in the answer it gave to the question, for reasons which we shall presently indicate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combines statutory agent status, business connection, disjunctive reading of s.4(1), and crediting as receipt; upholds High Court.

precedents.citation: Turner Morrison Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax  1

anchor.surface_text: Turner Morrison Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax  1

precedents.case_name: Turner Morrison Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: a person who is not an agent of the non-resident person can be appointed an agent for the purposes of s. 43 provided there subsists a business connection between him and the non-resident person; such agent is vicariously liable for the tax on income described in ss. 40 and 42
precedents.cited_holding: a person who is not an agent of the non-resident person can be appointed an agent for the purposes of s. 43, provided there subsists a business connection between him and the non-resident person. It was also held that such agent was vicariously liable for the tax on income described in ss.40 and 42

anchor.surface_text: Turner Morrisons case  1

precedents.case_name: Turner Morrison Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: the whole object of s.42 is to make certain income, profits and gains to be deemed to arise in India so as to bring them to charge; where income is actually received in India no recourse to the fiction of s.42 is necessary; s.4(1)(a) is general and applies to resident or non-resident unlike s.4(1)(b) or (c)
precedents.cited_holding: the whole object of that section s.42 is to make certain income, profits and gains to be deemed to arise in India so as to bring them to charge. The receipt of income, profits and gains being one of the tests of liability, where the income, profits and gains are actually received in India it is no longer necessary for the revenue authorities to have recourse to the fiction. Section 4 1 a in terms is, unlike Section 4 1 b or 4 1 c, not confined in its application, to any particular category of assessees

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court was right in answering the question against the assessee.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court decision upheld; commissions credited to non-resident's account deemed received in India under s.4(1)(a); assessee liable as statutory agent under s.42.

edges.explanation: The holding affirmatively states the assessee firm must be treated as statutory agent under sections 42 and 43, directly addressing the issue.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, there is no doubt that the assessee firm must be treated as a statutory agent. In Turner Morrison Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax  1 , this Court held that a person who is not an agent of the non- resident person can be appointed an agent for the purposes of s. 43, provided there subsists a business connection
In our opinion, the High Court was right in answering the question against the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no question in this case that a business connection subsisted during the years in question, and the appellant firm could be treated as an assessee for purposes of s. 42.
In our opinion, the High Court was right in answering the question against the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, clauses a and c of s.4 1 can be read disjunctively, and cl. a , which provides for receipt of income, profits and gains in the taxable territories cannot be subjected to the limitation that the income must also accrue or arise in the taxable territories.
In our opinion, the High Court was right in answering the question against the assessee.
